When searching via query, e.g. `http://devdocs.io/#q=lodash+templ`, the devdocs finds the correct API, refreshes window when it redirects (dunno why), and loads the API in the left menu, but __does not render__ the body:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5153846/24348042/a6f84996-12da-11e7-994e-6e8ef9ba8c1f.png)

I need to do additional refresh for it to work.

Stopped working since ~week ago (not sure).

Reproduced in chrome & FF stable.
Could you please make the devdocs menu (next to the search bar) open only when clicked? I find it keeps popping open when all I want to do is hover over the search and it's just distracting...

As discussed in the issue #593, here comes the pull request regarding the OpenJDK documentation. This work is base on the previous #560, thanks @japborst.

The documentation is sourced from [openjdk-8-doc_8u121-b13-4_all.deb](https://packages.debian.org/sid/openjdk-8-doc). Only the subdirectoy `usr/share/doc/openjdk-8-jre-headless/api` was extracted.

I've tried to include all packages and it's working fine for me, I don't experience any slow down. They are 217 types and 46 084 entries in 4 733 files occupying 153 MB. I think many other packages than the ones proposed in #560 are useful, like `javax.xml`. What do you think @Thibaut?

The highlighting issue is solved. Unfortunately Prism remove all `<a>` links inside `<pre>` tags but I haven't looked much into it. I don't think it's a big problem thought.

The Java documentation contains a lot of duplicated information, typically a summary of all methods and further down detail explanations for these methods. I tried to remove all these duplicates so the resulting documentation is lighter and easier to read.

I have reused the logos from the request #560, but I think they might be copyrighted and I'm not sure they can be used in Devdocs. I don't see this logo on the [OpenJDK](http://openjdk.java.net/) and [IcedTea](http://icedtea.classpath.org/wiki/Main_Page) websites. And the logo used in the [Java Wikipedia article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_(programming_language)) seems to be subject to fair use.
Very nice! I like it :-)

Thanks for an outstanding PR @freayd (and @japborst for the original PR).

> I've tried to include all packages and it's working fine for me, I don't experience any slow down. They are 217 types and 46 084 entries in 4 733 files occupying 153 MB.

I'm not too worried about the speed of the search. Even with 100k entries it seems to be holding up pretty well (I did a lot of optimization a while back).

However, I'm worried about search results becoming noisy / less useful due to the 46k entries, and increasing the chance that users will hit the IndexedDB quota and lose their offline data (until browsers implement the [Storage Standard](https://storage.spec.whatwg.org/), all website data is unfortunately non-persistent and subject to deletion when e.g. the device is low on disk space).

Since I expect this doc will be used by a large number of users, we should optimize/polish it as much as we can. A good number to shoot for would be ~20k entries (IIRC the biggest doc we have today is Drupal 8, with 12k entries).

Is AWT still actively used? Packages like `java.rmi` and `javax.management` can probably be left out / not useful to most people. Packages like `javax.xml` and `javax.swing` could be extracted in separate doc versions (see docs like Haxe and Tensorflow), but let's first try to get the number down as much as we can.

> I have reused the logos from the request #560, but I think they might be copyrighted and I'm not sure they can be used in Devdocs. I don't see this logo on the OpenJDK and IcedTea websites. And the logo used in the Java Wikipedia article seems to be subject to fair use.

I don't think we should use the Java logo, since we're adding OpenJDK. Please remove the logo and I'll figure something out. Also, please rename the doc/scraper "OpenJDK".

@Thibaut maybe should we split java packages into differents documentation, so Java AWT could be apart from "Java Core" (and some additionnal splits that we should think all together).

What do you think about it ?
Currently the scrollbars are thin and look nice, but when searching something on the page in Chrome, the found items are not shown in the scrollbar like in native Chrome.

Small bug:
When searching, appending a dash "-" doesn't show results. Example:
In the git documentation there is a function `git filter-branch`. Searching for `filter` or `filter-b` shows the function, but `filter-` shows nothing.

Adding this for information

This looks like the relevant line
https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/blob/master/assets/javascripts/app/searcher.coffee#L132 

The dash/hyphen is replaced with a dot "."

You can confirm this by searching for <S_CODE_TOKEN> , which shows a match for <S_CODE_TOKEN>

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1775342/24202160/abca6a12-0ee8-11e7-93da-c878ef46cc15.png)
Yeah searching with a dot works beautifully. Is there any reason the dashes should be replaced by dots?

> Is there any reason the dashes should be replaced by dots?

There is. The search uses a bunch of heuristics to efficiently rank results. Among other things, the [ranking algo](https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/blob/44ade1865ee9292e18e41662a782328c3cbbb3e6/assets/javascripts/app/searcher.coffee#L34-L74) looks at the presence/position of "separators" (`.`, `#`, etc.) in the matching string relative to the search query, to give higher scores to results like `document.head`, over `Headers`, when searching for `head` — thereby greatly improving the search results. For performance reasons, all "separators" are replaced by dots in the search strings/queries, so that all "separators" are just one and the same character (this makes the search orders of magnitude faster).

Dashes are considered "separators" so that results like `linear-gradient()` rank higher than `CanvasGradient` when searching for `gradient`. However, dashes are only considered "separators" when they're followed by a word character, so that searching for `-` doesn't match everything. As you can see, in-browser search is hard/tricky science 😛 

I have a fix in 9d919591c2fd739a972cea02b47421df41e5c183.

Ah I see. That is actually super interesting stuff! Did you come up with the heuristic yourself? I must admit that the search works really well as the desired functions are always at the top of the query results.

Hey all,

I'm planning on adding the Java documentation using the OpenJDK 8. Before I dig into anything, I'd like to know if the [OpenJDK license](http://openjdk.java.net/legal/gplv2+ce.html) (GPL v2 with the Classpath Exception) is compatible with the DevDocs projects?

If so then I'll be submitting a pull request for it.

Thanks.

Hey!

Yes, the GPLv2 is compatible with DevDocs / MPLv2.

Which source are you planning to use? Ideally we'd use pre-generated docs from somewhere. I'm on macOS and would rather not have to build OpenJDK / the docs locally if we can avoid it.

That's great then.

Let me look a bit a the possibilities and I'll see if I can find some pre-generated documentation.

Would that be an option for you to start from any Linux distribution package like [Debian](https://packages.debian.org/sid/openjdk-8-doc) or [Ubuntu](http://packages.ubuntu.com/yakkety/openjdk-8-doc)? Will have to check their respective licensing thought. Are you already using any Linux distribution for other documentations?

Sorry, no. Every documentation is coming from a web/downloaded source, except the Ruby/Rails docs which are generated with a Ruby command-line tool.

Is there any way to turn these packages into HTML files without setting up an entire distro?

I also found http://linuxsoft.cern.ch/cern/slc63/i386/yum/updates/repoview/java-1.8.0-openjdk-javadoc.html and https://www.archlinux.org/packages/extra/x86_64/openjdk8-doc/.

FYI someone wrote a scraper for the SE documentation in https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/pull/560. We might be able to reuse parts of it for the OpenJDK scraper.
/cc @japborst, did you end up looking into OpenJDK?

As far as I understand, there is nothing else than sources provided by the OpenJDK project. So one option would be to download the sources and compile them which will generate the documentation.

Each Linux distribution provides packages, which are built by themselves from the sources. It is interesting to note that Linux distributions sometimes patch the original sources for various reasons, like adapting it to their platform or fixing bugs. Debian, Ubuntu, Arch Linux and the CERN all provide an OpenJDK documentation package containing a set of HTML files.

IMHO, I recommend starting from the Debian (the most reliable distribution, 23 years old now…) package. A package is a .deb file which is basically an archive. The Debian package is "built using the [IcedTea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IcedTea) build support and patches". My main concern still is the license, as the Debian, IcedTea and a few other building tools license is now coming up. @Thibaut can you please have a look at the [copyright file](https://gist.github.com/freayd/0d6333f9fd100cd0c416f46a1624f873) of the current Debian package and let me know if you think it is compatible with DevDocs? Thanks.

I've downloaded all four packages, and the documentation in each says:

> This document is the API specification for the Java™ Platform, Standard Edition.

and seems identical to http://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/.

@freayd I'm not worried about the license of building tools like IcedTea. OpenJDK is licensed under GPLv2, so any derivative work has to also be licensed under GPLv2.

What I'm more worried about is whether those packages actually contain documentation built from the OpenJDK source code, and whether the GPL license applies or not. The packaging/UI of those docs indicate otherwise. Could you maybe ask for clarification on the OpenJDK mailing list?

I just spent a bit of time learning about the subject. I can't explain things better than these links (but I'll try to my best to summarize what I understood from them):
- [Wikipedia - Java Licensing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_(software_platform)#Licensing)
- [Wikipedia - OpenJDK / IcedTea inclusion in software distributions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OpenJDK#IcedTea_and_inclusion_in_software_distributions)
- [OpenJDK - FAQ](http://openjdk.java.net/faq/)
- [Ubuntu - Java](https://help.ubuntu.com/community/Java)
- [Debian - Java](https://wiki.debian.org/Java)

There are several Java implementations, such as OpenJDK, Oracle Java but also many others. All are supposed to be compatible, some fully, others not. But each version has indeed its own license and some share common code.

OpenJDK is a set of the opened classes under GPL. It is actually actively developed by Oracle but also many other contributors. The Oracle Java is built on top of the OpenJDK. Oracle provides some closed source additional classes/features to their Java SE and even more to their Java EE. The IcedTea project aims to implement an alternative GPL code to every bit of Oracle Java SE closed source features. Most of the Oracle Java SE is actually open (from OpenJDK), only bits of it are closed source which explains the great similarity between the Oracle Java SE documentations and the OpenJDK / IcedTea one.

Major Linux distributions ship so called OpenJDK packages which are actually built from IcedTea sources (based on OpenJDK). Debian & Ubuntu also provide packages for the older GCJ (GNU Compiler for Java), a no longer maintained alternative. There is also an IBM Java which isn't included in Debian nor Ubuntu, but IBM provides package for these distributions. As for the Oracle JDK SE, since 2011 Debian and Ubuntu no longer have the permission to distribute it, so instead Oracle provide binaries from its website.

If you still want to get a confirmation from the OpenJDK mailing list, we could try it but the OpenJDK FAQ contains: 
> Can I expect to get specific legal advice or answers to my legal questions on OpenJDK mailing lists? In general, no. The OpenJDK mailing lists serve for technical work around development of specific OpenJDK projects.

The Debian OpenJDK package seems to be built form OpenJDK + IcedTea Sound + Java Access Bridge + the package code (maintened by Matthias Klose). Once more, all its licensing information is contained under its [copyright file](https://bazaar.launchpad.net/~openjdk/openjdk/openjdk8/view/head:/debian/copyright). I think if one thing needs to be double checked and reviewed, it is this file. This is the [Debian source package](https://packages.debian.org/source/sid/openjdk-8) and the [source repository on Launchpad](https://code.launchpad.net/~openjdk/openjdk/openjdk8).

I just installed the openjdk documentation through `sudo apt install openjdk-8-doc`, which results in the same documentation as the Oracle docs in `/usr/share/doc/openjdk-8-doc/api/`. Also it shows the Oracle copyright at the bottom of the files:
> Copyright © 1993, 2017, Oracle and/or its affiliates. All rights reserved. Use is subject to license terms. Also see the documentation redistribution policy.

The [doc redistribution policy](http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/redist-137594.html) states:
> **Documentation**  The Java SE API Specification is not redistributable. One exception is granted, where permission is given to publish 10 or fewer unaltered screen shots of our documentation, whose intended purpose is to show examples of our work. Unaltered screen shots include web pages, our Java applets, our demo applets and applications, and listings of their source code.
> **API specifications** can be redistributed internally without special permission. They cannot be made available on the Internet.

So to answer your question, @Thibaut, the docs are _not_ generated from the OpenJDK source.

@freayd Thanks a lot for looking into this. 

I believe you're correct and the documentation is licensed under the terms/licenses described in the [copyright file](https://bazaar.launchpad.net/%7Eopenjdk/openjdk/openjdk8/view/head:/debian/copyright). I've looked at the source code of the OpenJDK package distributed on Debian and confirmed that the documentation is embedded in the source. This means the terms of GPLv2 license should apply to it, and any derivative work, including the API docs package, should also be licensed under GPLv2, regardless of Oracle's documentation redistribution policy (as long as the package was built from OpenJDK sources).

Additionally, if Oracle's documentation redistribution policy did apply to those packages, then Debian/Ubuntu/etc. would be violating it, as they are in fact redistributing the docs on their websites.

So I think we're good to redistribute the OpenJDK docs (downloaded from the Debian or Ubuntu repository) on DevDocs. I'll try to tackle this in the coming weeks, using [@japborst's PR](https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/pull/560) as a starting point.

Great news and thanks for helping.

I was going to start writing the necessary code, just waiting to be sure about the license compatibility. If you don't mind @Thibaut I can work on it in the next few days and send a new PR based on the previous one from japborst.

Gem - [simplecov](https://github.com/colszowka/simplecov)
Simplecov is a code coverage analysis tool for Ruby. It uses Ruby's built-in Coverage library to gather code coverage data, but makes processing its results much easier by providing a clean API to filter, group, merge, format, and display those results.

Code coverage of your code is above 95% right now. Which is amazing !!
Using this tool you can have a better idea about your code getting covered. It'll help you write more test cases for covering missed/loose scenarios.

I hope you like it. Sorry I did not open any issue to discuss about the feature/improvement.
Thanks for the PR, but I'm interested in using Simplecov. It adds overhead for little benefit (in the case of codebase like DevDocs's).

Hello!

Devdocs is amazing for docs searching, just as Sublime Text is awesome for writing code. And, here's what I'd like to do: combine both of them, just like it's possible with atom.

Since Sublime Text now supports phantoms which allows it to [display basic html](http://www.sublimetext.com/docs/3/api_reference.html#sublime.Phantom) in the code, it's now very tempting to do a great plugin for ST using devdocs.

The problem is that ST just renders html, know's [very few CSS properties](http://www.sublimetext.com/docs/3/minihtml.html), so, JavaScript is pretty far from being supported. So, I thought there'd be an API like this maybe:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

that'd give us a `404`, or just the doc for this particular function.

But, it looks like it's not the case... So, would it be possible to build it? Or all the search algorithm are on the client's side?

Thanks for devdocs, and in advance 😉 

Matt

Hey - thanks!

See #133. An API would require a significant investment in time, maintenance, and hosting costs. I agree it would be useful, but unfortunately I don't have the time to tackle this, as DevDocs is just a side-project of mine.

Currently the search happens entirely client-side, which makes it fast, work offline, and cheap.

If I let the doc slug use the default, by downcasing the doc name, we might as well clean it up so it is routable.

As it is, if the name has a dash in it, it breaks if you try to load a page from the doc directly (it still works when browsing it by js navigation).
I dropped the ~ I initially had in the regexp, as I realized it is used as separator for the version part of the slug, and thus should not be included here.
I'll take a look at the failing test cases.
Added test case to verify functionality.

Hey - thanks for the PR.

I'd prefer we raise an error when the slug (generated from the name) contains illegal characters, rather than replace those characters with `_`. 

Docs with non-alphanumeric character in the name should always have an explicit `slug` defined. E.g. `C++`, `LÖVE`, `Ruby / Minitest` (in all those cases, the generated slug in this PR would be incorrect).

Can we make devdocs a chrome extension instead of a chrome app?
Based on this article, google shall remove chrome apps in the next few months...
http://www.theverge.com/2016/8/19/12555052/google-shutting-down-chrome-apps
Also having a visual indicator before going offline on the extensions pane is a nice reminder to (Feature:) click on it and let it re-install documentation for offline use.

I have no plans to make a Chrome extension as of now, since I know nothing about Chrome extensions and have my plate full with other features + new docs already. AFAIK the benefit of an extension for something like DevDocs is quite small, given that the website works just as well (the Chrome app is actually just a shortcut to the website).

If someone wants to take a crack at it, feel free to and I'll be happy to bring the code under the DevDocs umbrella (but please do not create an extension called "DevDocs" without my approval).

The direct replacement of a chrome app that handles a web page url is a service worker, and I see Thibaut has plans to make one for devdocs. 

An extension as a full replacement of the app wouldn't be able to keep devdocs.io url in the browser address bar, there will be the ugly chrome-extension://blablabla/something. Of course one can write an extension that injects itself in devdocs.io as a content script and creates/handles absolutely everything on the page but that's weird and won't allow accessing devdocs without a network connection to the actual site. Service workers can provide such access.

Even though a chrome extension isn't required, a companion extension could be written (by a third party developer, for example) to provide some indication/access from the browser toolbar and other parts. When and if that happens, devdocs may consider adding an API endpoint for such third party extensions by using e.g. chrome.runtime.onMessageExternal for whitelisted extensions or DOM custom events that may be sent from/to an extension's content script injected into devdocs.io page.

One example of such companion extension could be an [omnibox search provider](https://developer.chrome.com/extensions/omnibox) that registers a keyword in the browser so the users can type that keyword in the address bar and the extension will show autocomplete suggestions for the text input by querying devdocs API or do something more complex like [omnibox for github](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/omnibox-for-github/jbfhklldhgbomclinhlgbmjjiimafolo) does.

> The direct replacement of a chrome app that handles a web page url is a service worker, and I see Thibaut has plans to make one for devdocs.

I intend to implement Service Worker as soon as Safari supports it. Until then, it's not worth the effort, because I wouldn't be able to remove the old AppCache code (which works well enough).

- I switched the syntax highlighting code to be more generic a while ago (sorry the wiki/docs aren't great :/). See [`simple.coffee`](https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/blob/master/assets/javascripts/views/pages/simple.coffee). Just add a `data-language` attribute (and remove all existing highlighting) to the `pre` elements in the `clean_html` filter, then no need for a dedicated coffee file. 
- For readability, all pages should begin with a top-level `<h1>` element.
- It's sometimes easier to run the `entries` filter before `clean_html`, or vice-versa (e.g. when `clean_html` modifies headings).
- `include_default_entry?` should never return `false` when the page has additional entries. I did this in the past and it causes issues, because then `/page#frag` works, but `/page` doesn't, which leads to broken links. The only remaining use-case for `include_default_entry?` is when you want to visit a page but not index/store it at all (e.g. if the page has links not found on other pages).
- `self.release` → full release number
- Indent with 2 spaces.

Lastly: I may not always accept docs with less than ~3k GitHub stars, as it takes time to maintain/update them. Feel free to email me to check before doing the work.
Thanks @Thibaut for the notes, I will use them for the next scraper. Next documentation will be [Composer](https://github.com/composer/composer) with more than 3k start.

I think this issue is a Linux version of #51.

The current keyboard shortcuts for navigating forward and back are `Control-Left` and `Control-Right`. Unfortunately I've got into the habit of using these keybindings in Chrome (53) on Linux (Ubuntu 14.04) to navigate to the start or end of a word in a text box, such as the main search field. It's a bit frustrating when I mean to focus the cursor at the start of the field but instead go back to the previous page! I'm not sure if this a GNOME convention or something that's used in general across multiple desktop environments.

[Firefox](https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/keyboard-shortcuts-perform-firefox-tasks-quickly#w_navigation), [Chrome](https://support.google.com/chrome/answer/157179?hl=en-GB), [IE 11](https://support.microsoft.com/en-gb/help/15357/windows-internet-explorer-11-keyboard-shortcuts) and [Edge](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/13805/windows-keyboard-shortcuts-in-apps) already use `Alt-Left` and `Alt-Right` for forward/back; [Opera](http://help.opera.com/Linux/9.50/en/keyboard.html) apparently uses either `Alt-` or `Control-` in combination with `Left` and `Right`. I'm not a Mac user, but (in the interest of completeness) the forward/back word shortcuts are apparently [`Option-Left` and `Option-Right`](https://support.apple.com/en-gb/HT201236) and Safari's back/forward page shortcuts are [`Command-[` and `Command-]`](https://www.domainit.com/tools/mac-shortcuts.mhtml).

Maybe devdocs should use `Alt-Direction' for navigation? Or perhaps don't listen for page forward/back shortcuts when the search box is focused?
Sorry for the delay. I made it so the keyboard shortcut for back/forward is `Alt+Left/Right` on all platforms but Mac.

Use DevDocs via HTTPS (i.e. as https://devdocs.io/offline -- notice the `s`).  I do think that there should be some kind of redirect from HTTP to HTTPS for just this reason, though.

Hi - AppCache is still fully functional in Chrome. The deprecation notice is just that, a notice, and as far as I know the Chrome team has no plans to remove AppCache in the near future (they started collecting data early this year and there has been no activity on [the bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=588931) since).

As @JesseTG said you can use DevDocs over HTTPS. The reason HTTPS isn't the default is because there are a number of docs that still have insecure images, which trigger mixed content warnings (or would fail to load if HTTPS was enforced).
Thanks!

The supersmall (5kB) and superfast [lz-string](https://github.com/pieroxy/lz-string/) library compresses data stored by devdocs.io in localStorage to 14% of its original size as tested here with 8 docs activated: 1980kB vs 267kB.

DevDocs uses `localStorage` simply as an extra cache for the index files, on top of AppCache, to make the app boot as quickly as possible. If `localStorage` is full, there is little impact on performance, and offline availability is still complete (because the index files are also in AppCache, which acts as a fallback for any index file that the app doesn't find in `localStorage`).

So compressing the data would yield little benefit (a couple MBs of storage on the device), but at the cost of a slower app, since no matter how fast lz-string is, it'll still take quite a bit of CPU to uncompress all this data (which happens at a critical time: when the app boots).

Compressing the offline data stored in `IndexedDB` (content of the docs) would yield more benefit, as this data can amount to 10s of MBs, but again performance would take a hit (when opening docs). In my opinion, performance is more important than storage space, as the amount of storage the app uses is pretty small in comparison to other apps, and speed is key to the UX / usability of the app.

Does it save library enabled data in localStorage?

I'm pretty sure the enabled docs are saved in an IndexedDB:
![devdocs](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3207763/19766540/d9ee3de0-9c4e-11e6-85af-8d7a5d75de1d.png)
@FelixRilling `IndexDB`, amazing! But when I clear storage, It seems my data will be clear. I have to enabled each library again. So I want to sync my data in cloud.

All settings (selection of docs, color scheme, etc.) are stored in cookies. Firefox and Chrome have built-in sync that can synchronize cookies. There's also a number of browser extensions that can do this. Just use one of those and you'll be all set.

IndexedDB is only used for the offline data, which is kept up-to-date automatically. It's not something that can be synced (it already syncs with DevDocs's servers). See also https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/issues/336.

Is there a way to optionally disable the default keyboard shortcuts? I'm facing a problem similar to #77, because I'm using [Pentadactyl](http://5digits.org/pentadactyl/index), which provides Vim-like shortcuts that are clashing with the page shortcuts.

Specifically I'm facing problems when I perform a search on the page contents:
- `/` : open the search line (similar to Vim)
- `<pattern>`: enter a pattern to search
- `<cr>`: end the input, jump to the first result

The problem is that when the <kbd>Enter</kbd> (last step above) is hit the cursor moves to search box (on the top left of the page). I've played with some Pentadactyl `:map` commands in order to change the behavior of `<cr>` when browsing http://devdocs.io/ but no luck so far.

The help at http://devdocs.io/help mentions that it is possible to select options through the URL:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

It would be nice if I could disable the keyboard shortcuts on the URL as well:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I think this is very much an edge case / not something that most people need, so I'm a bit reluctant to make it a feature. You can disable keyboard shortcuts after the app has loaded by running `app.shortcuts.stop()`, which you could automate using something like Greasemonkey. Does that address your use-case?

This is probably an issue for every Vimperator/Pentadactyl user, but I have no idea how many people use it, so maybe it is an edge case used for too few people.

To be honest I was hopping for a simpler solution, because I don't know Greasemonkey and it seems an overkill to install another extension in order to disable a shortcut in a single site (and hope this doesn't mess with Pentadactyl).

If this kind of issue should be handled by the user them it is probably better to solve it directly on Pentadactyl, as it has several options and mappings for keys. Those options/mappings allowed to solve similar issues in several other sites; I'm having some trouble here because the shortcut involves the <kbd>Enter</kbd> key, so remapping it to <nop> disables the default shortcut but also prevents the search in Pentadactyl (because search & commands are delimited by the <kbd>Enter</kbd>).

As I've run out of ideas to make this work using mappings, I've tried to use your suggestion of calling the javascript code you mentioned. Pentadactyl [provides a function to execute javascript](http://5digits.org/help/pentadactyl/eval.xhtml#:js), and based [in an example at superuser](http://superuser.com/questions/891648/) I tested this:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

This stopped the shortcuts when browsing the page, but for some reason it is still triggered when finishing the search on Pentadactyl's search line. I'm wondering if the command above is entered on one frame, and the search triggers the shortcut in a different frame. Is there any javascript call that disables the shortcuts more globally/forcefully?

> Is there any javascript call that disables the shortcuts more globally/forcefully?

`app.shortcuts.stop()` forcefully disables all keyboard shortcuts, but if the app hasn't finished loading yet, then those shortcuts will be re-enabled as part of the loading process. Is there an option in Pentadactyl to run some JavaScript only once the page has finished loading?

Yes, I think there is a way to do that in Pentadactyl. But the test I reported was manual (waited the page load and them typed the command), so I think we have another problem here. (I've just repeated the test in order to be completely sure that the page had finished loading, and I got the same results)

I've given this more thought and decided not to add a setting to disable all shortcuts, since only a handful of users would use it, and it might be confusing / the wrong solution to other users' problems.

DevDocs isn't in the business of writing docs, so we'd need to find a good source that allows its docs to be modified and redistributed.
@Thibaut Why not just the `man` pages?

@JesseTG if only it was that simple :P There are 100,000s of man pages. Adding all of them to DevDocs would make the search unusable. There are also different man pages for different OSs. But the biggest hurdle is that DevDocs currently only supports scraping HTML, and I'm not aware of any man pages documentation that can be downloaded in HTML format and freely redistributed.

@Thibaut So get choosy.  Maybe stick with [whatever GNU provides](https://www.gnu.org/software/software.html); I get the feeling that requests for "command line docs" are really requests for "GNU software" (since a large part of the Unix ecosystem is shaped by them).  I think these packages alone could satisfy a lot of people:
- [`bash`](https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/)
- [`coreutils`](https://www.gnu.org/software/coreutils/coreutils.html) (this is a big one)
- [`gettext`](https://www.gnu.org/software/gettext/)
- [`gnupg`](https://www.gnu.org/software/gnupg/)
- [`autoconf`](https://www.gnu.org/software/autoconf/autoconf.html) (and the rest of the `autotools` suite)
- [`bc`](https://www.gnu.org/software/bc/)
- [`binutils`](https://www.gnu.org/software/binutils/)
- [`bison`](https://www.gnu.org/software/bison/)
- [`findutils`](https://www.gnu.org/software/findutils/)

- [`sed`](https://www.gnu.org/software/sed/), another big one

Hello and thanks for the great work!

I've enabled the documentation for Django 1.10, and I'm typing, for example, `ALLOWED_HOSTS` in the search field. Unfortunately nothing is coming up, even though this can be found by manually locating `http://devdocs.io/django~1.10/ref/settings` after typing `settings`. 

Is this an overall limitation of the devdocs.io search functionality or a specific issue with the Django docs indexing? I'm thinking the latter, since in Python 3 I'm able to search for stuff that doesn't have their own page, like `str.split`.

Help?

Hi

Every entry in DevDocs's index is manually indexed (as in there is code in the scraper that goes look for it). It's not like Google where you can just search anything and it'll find anything (that wouldn't work offline in a browser). So as you said it's primarily a limitation of the DevDocs search.

However, in this case it should be possible to index the headings on that page so that each becomes an entry in the search index. The trick is to index only the headings that should appear in the search index (things like "Introduction", "Overview", etc. should not). I'll try to do that next time I update the Django docs.

Thanks for the feedback.
Thank you for the detailed and informative reply. Any improvements welcome.

In some python-based documentation, jupyter notebook or iPython code cells are used. These are not properly recognised by the sphinx html cleaner. Example: http://devdocs.io/pandas~0.18/10min

Additionally, such notebooks may contain data:image URIs for images, which are currently replaced by '#' as those are deemed invalid. This fix simply skips any sanitising for these.

As indicated in e.g. #331, MathML is not supported in DevDocs in unsupported browsers such as Chrome.  This PR uses the same CSS fallback [Mozilla uses](https://developer.cdn.mozilla.net/static/styles/libs/mathml.css) in their docs, that originates from this repo [fred-wang/mathml.css](https://github.com/fred-wang/mathml.css): example [Math.PI](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Math/PI) This method is doc-agnostic, so will also work for all other docs that uses MathML. 

Process is as follows:
1. Check for MathML support
2. Sideload CSS if not existent

This method saves bandwidth and is thus faster if MathML is supported. However, currently it sideloads the CSS externally.

2 possible alternatives:
1. Sideload the CSS locally (couldn't figure out how to do that in the set-up of DevDocs, unfortunatly)
2. Alter the css with a `.fallback` class, include in `application.css.scss` and apply class if not supported. However, the docs are not present on load so applying the class makes it difficult.

Whilst [MathJax](https://www.mathjax.org/) provides much better support, it is rather immense...

Feedback is welcome.
Merged in 4c28cb6dbdd22b58cee98d1824c0f1f59d45d97d and added the local CSS in a8bd4227c3377d63b7e018ecb95f2eaff9c7328d. Thanks!

Hello there! 

Thank you for this awesome platform of documentations!

I'm really used to scroll pages via my arrow keys, so I expect this behavior on pretty any page. especially on documentation.

I understand that arrow keys are used for the sidebar, since you want to quickly get to your search results, whenever you type something.

**My suggestion:**
Instead of changing the default user experience for navigating through content to shift+arrowkey, I would only add eventhandlers for the results after something has been searched. Otherwise - when do you need to quickly navigate through pages other than the search results?

So maybe on Enter/Blur - we could switch back to navigate content rather than page items.

Please let me know what your thoughts are.

Hi - thanks for the feedback.

The arrow keys are also used to navigate the hierarchy of docs/categories/classes,functions,etc in the sidebar — not just for the search results. I think it's best to keep the behavior of the arrow keys consistent throughout the app.

Thanks for the suggestion. I think making backspace not clear the search scope when the search field is empty would be confusing/annoying to the average user. IMO it's the expected behavior.

There are already multiple ways to clear the search field without resetting the scope:

- by clicking the "X" icon (which can be focused/activated by hitting `tab`)

I had to revert this because it causes the keyboard to pop up on iOS when the app is added to the homescreen. The actual bug sounds like a browser bug, though. What does `$.isTouchScreen()` in the web console return on Linux?

I'm very sorry - I might have caused the problem myself. Either Ubuntu distributed Firefox with touch events (`ontouchstart` et. al.) enabled or _I_'m the culprit and enabled them and forgot I tampered with those settings. Disabling them in `about:config` fixes the issue for me. I guess there is currently no way of detecting whether a focused input actually triggers a soft keyboard to pop up.

There is a [Stackoverflow comment](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3974827/detecting-touch-screen-devices-with-javascript#comment-19047102) on this topic, that however doesn't really help.
@th-we no worries. `$.isTouchScreen()` could probably be improved to detect touch devices that also have a keyboard.

I stumbled upon this issue by being unable to find documentation for `typing.NewType` [introduced in Python 3.5.2](https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/changelog.html#python-3-5-2). Comparing [the page for the `typing` module on DevDocs](https://devdocs.io/python%7E3.5/library/typing#type-aliases) with [its official source](https://docs.python.org/3.5/library/typing.html#type-aliases), you can see that the first section should have more content, and the section following it is missing.

Looking further, I have noticed that [the official docs](https://docs.python.org/3.5/library/index.html) for the latest stable Python version (with "Python » 3.5.2 Documentation" showing on the top) keep receiving updates even after the release on 2016-06-26. [According to their repo](https://github.com/python/cpython/commits/3.5/Doc/library?page=2), there are about 60 commits on their 3.5 branch touching the docs as shown on their website that are missing in the DevDocs snapshot. "Issue #24136" from Jun 12 is there (listed in the changelog under "Python 3.5.2 release candidate 1"), but not the following commit "Issue #27221", or "Issue #16182" (listed under "Python 3.5.3 release candidate 1").

My guess is that the missing changes are technically meant to 'ship' with 3.5.3. But since they seem to be mostly fixes for mistakes or missing/outdated info in the docs, they are shown on the official site immediately, even the ones commited as recently as today ([[1]](https://docs.python.org/3.5/library/typing.html#typing.AnyStr), [[2]](https://github.com/python/cpython/commit/2a50a4e347bdf898e629d3078d521295072e3977)).

In other words, if that's not too much effort, I propose that the Python docs should be (auto-)updated more often.

Updating docs is a manual process. I can only do it as often as my spare time allows and must balance spending time updating docs with adding new ones and improving the app. Updating docs in between releases doesn't make the cut because most of the time there are no significant changes in the documentation, and I'd rather spend my time on higher-impact things.

Fully automating the update process is not realistic at this stage given the architecture of DevDocs and my limited spare time.
I understand, and it's totally fine. I was just surprised to discover that Python docs receive these updates continuously, and thought it was accidentally not taken into account in DevDocs.

I just tested on Android 4.0.4, and it allowed to Install Offline data for all "default package" (CSS, HTML, JavaScript, etc.) except DOM (21.9Mb). On Install it it crashes (shows "Aw, Snap!" screen), perhaps exceeds offline limit. The same would happen if I would try to Install PHP (21.4 Mb).
Resource http://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/offline/quota-research/ (might be outdated).

For better UX, I think it would be better instead to handle IndexedDB limit and show warning. Maybe splitting the "packages" to smaller sizes and Installing one after another would avoid this crash.

Unfortunately there is currently no way to programmatically detect how much storage is available in IndexedDB, or even how much is being used. Once the quota is exceeded IndexedDB throws an error and the only thing the app can do is delete the database and start over :/

This might be because in most browsers the quota is based on the amount of free space on the device, which is always changing. There's a [spec](https://storage.spec.whatwg.org/) being worked on to help with this but it seems pretty far off.

However, the fact that you're seeing the "Aw, Snap!" screen is a different issue. This means the browser crashed, and browsers should never crash. Please report the bug in the [Chrome bug tracker](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/list). Not much I can do from DevDocs's side.

I'm running Firefox Aurora on Android Lollipop and, both times DevDocs has asked me to reload to apply an update, it resets the list of selected docs to CSS, DOM, DOM Events, HTML, HTTP, and JavaScript.

This doesn't affect the downloaded content as, once I reselect the docs I want, it's listed as downloaded and up to date on the Offline page.

Given that my privacy extensions tie cookies and all other stored content together under the same preference (meaning the same rules govern downloaded docs and the list of selected docs), it shouldn't be my privacy extensions at fault.

Please disable your privacy extensions and see if the problem still happens. The selected docs are stored in a cookie and no one else has reported a similar problem, so I can't think of another explanation than your extensions are interfering with cookies.

PS: the downloaded docs are stored in a different place than the selection itself (IndexedDB vs. cookies).

At the moment, I can't test anything since my only Android device had to be returned after the LCD cable failed (fixed lines in display output) and I use Zeal for reading docs on my desktop.

(However, I did make an `adb backup` image, so I'll be able to test once I get some new hardware to restore it to.)

It shouldn't be the extension, though, since:
1. The behaviour I observed had it persisting the selection beyond the "10 seconds after the last devdocs tab is closed" point.
2. It's set to flush all stored state on the same trigger to limit the effectiveness of supercookies. It'd do a pretty poor job of that if it omitted IndexedDB.

With the information I have, the only explanation is that something is blocking (or deleting) cookies on the device, which is outside of DevDocs's control. The code that stores the doc selection has been in production for 2+ years without issues.

If you're able to replicate with all extensions disabled, let me know and I'll reopen this.

@ZashIn Thanks a lot for the screenshots. It seems you're missing the`schema` cookie. Without it, the app will try to open the IDB database with a version number that doesn't match the one in IDB. 

Could you run `Cookies.get('schema')` in the console. If you get nothing, try running `Cookies.set('schema', '10', path: '/', expires: 1e8)`, and see if you get an error.

@Thibaut Thank you, the cookie was the problem, indeed:
`Cookies.get('schema')` returned nothing = no cookie.
With `Cookies.set('schema', '10', {path: '/', expires: 1e8})` (you missed the braces for the third argument) the offline feature works again.
So this problem probably comes down to my cookie settings: I forgot the exception from the session cookies ;)

@ZashIn it's still weird that the app managed to save other cookies, but not the `schema` one. They all use the same options. What do you mean by:

>  I forgot the exception from the session cookies

I am using firefox with session cookies = delete cookies when closing firefox.
But I was wrong anyway, that cannot be the source of the problem, since I tested it on a fresh profile with default cookie settings (keep until they expire).

After further testing, it seems like the sheme cookie is only set after downloading all the (default) offline content. It is not set when I download just one or a few decumentations, but I am not sure when exacly it is set.
So if the cookie is required for IDB database but only set when creating / downloading the database, then deleting the cookies without (fully) clearing the database leads to a corrupted state, as you said, right?:

> the app will try to open the IDB database with a version number that doesn't match the one in IDB.

The `schema` cookie is only set (the first time) and incremented after certain actions (enabling/disabling docs, clicking "Install all"). Its presence isn't required if you haven't performed those actions yet. I'll try to add logging in the code that sets the cookie, to detect when it isn't saved properly.
I had same issue 2 days ago. Executing `Cookies.set('schema', '10', {path: '/', expires: 1e8})` helped to solve problem in my browser (Firefox 50.1.0, Linux). Not fixed yet.

_Repeatable:_ When remote slugs contain characters unsafe for the local file system (in my case NTFS on Windows 7)

_Steps to repeat:_
1. Clone my [fork](https://github.com/nucular/devdocs/tree/love) for the LÖVE scraper (at the time of writing HEAD of the branch `love`)
2. Run `thor docs:page love Canvas:renderTo` (which might fail because the `docs:page` command is broken, just remove the check at [lib/tasks/docs.thor#L34:L36](https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/blob/master/lib/tasks/docs.thor#L34:L36) for now).

_Expected result:_ `public/docs/love/canvas:renderto.html` (or similar) is generated.

_Actual result:_ `public/docs/love/canvas` is generated.

While writing a scraper for the [LÖVE](http://love2d.org) engine documentation I ran into an issue where remote pages with colons in their slugs (for example [Canvas:renderTo](https://love2d.org/wiki/Canvas:renderTo)) are being written to files named like the slug up to the first colon (for example `public/docs/love/canvas`). This results both in subsequent pages overwriting this file and in the client not being able to find this file under the expected path.

I would fix this problem myself in a pull-request, but I am neither sure where path sanitization logic would be appropriately placed (I assume in `Docs.Doc#path`) nor what to replace unsafe characters with to keep the integrity of other documentations.

Hey - sorry for the late reply.
Try adding `options[:decode_and_clean_paths] = true` to your scraper.

Thanks for the help!
When enabling that option pages are being stored in appropriate paths, but links to them from other pages don't seem to be affected by this (`canvas`instead of `canvas-renderto.html`). I have tried regenerating the entire documentation from a clean slate, but the problem persists.
Rebase with master and it should work :) (fix is in 2813cf9be32cf6f2dc69abca75069084d871aeb6)

I'm writing a scraper for the perl docs, and they use manpage-style formatting with a series of sections. Each section starts: `

OO Perl

` and the `` gets removed by the built-in filters in devdocs. The links between sections are useful though - what is the intended solution for this?

In your `clean_html` filter, move the `name` attribute of those links to an `id` attribute on the next element. That way the element (heading) will be highlighted correctly in the UI when scrolled to, and we can keep removing all empty tags, some of which can often break stuff.

E.g. https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/blob/905d6cee9e3e1c9737088f7fb4da53d1c28453ad/lib/docs/filters/nginx/clean_html.rb#L15-L18

DevDocs is more about reference & API docs than guides & tutorials, because the latter is harder to index (needs full-text search, which Google will always be better at than DevDocs). So I prefer not to create sub-entries for guides & tutorials. You can always use `ctrl/cmd+f` to search within a page.

Thanks but I'm not ready to make HTTPS the default just yet:
- some docs still have insecure assets (images)
- localStorage and IndexedDB are per-origin, so if a user switches from HTTP to HTTPS, they'll lose their offline data. To make HTTPS the default we'll need an upgrade path + to hard-redirect HTTP → HTTPS, so users don't accidentally go back and end up with outdated or missing offline data. 

I've been switching many docs/scrapers to HTTPS in recent months. Once 90%+ support HTTPS or don't have insecure assets, I'll make the switch.

This PR points to a few links that should be made protocol-relative, though. I'll fix that in a separate commit.

Feature request.
There is a feature when you can launch chrome app in dedicated window (like [google keep](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/google-keep-notes-and-lis/hmjkmjkepdijhoojdojkdfohbdgmmhki)). Chrome provides support for different OSs so you can launch it like a native app.

If Chrome app starts in a new window you can avoid additional searching of particular tab with app and you can navigate through the windows easily.

You don't need a Chrome app to do this.

Here's how to do it on Windows:
1. Go to DevDocs in Chrome.
2. Open _Hamburger menu_ > _More tools_ > _Add to desktop..._
3. Make sure to check the _Open as window_ option.

Sorry I should have explained before closing. I don't know why Chrome doesn't turn that option "on" by default. Probably because it's still experimental / not completely stable. Hopefully they'll enable it for everyone soon.

Apps that work without the option are "packaged" apps. DevDocs is a "hosted" app. Packaged apps are built specifically for Chrome, whereas hosted apps are just website shortcuts.

Making DevDocs a packaged app would require rewriting a big chunk of the JS without [these APIs](https://developer.chrome.com/apps/app_deprecated), and then maintaining two codebases (because the web app can't do without Chrome's disabled APIs). This isn't something I'm interested in doing, sorry.

@PombaM I think the scope for devdocs is to provide information about code. What can be better for understanding code than quickly trying to code?
I understand that it isn't simple to implement, and there are troubles with versioning, dependencies, repl integration, and probably more. But I think it can be long-term improvement that will make devdocs closer to the single and complete source of data about popular libraries.

@PombaM docs.angularjs.org facebook.github.io/react/docs lodash.com/docs ramdajs.com/docs

I agree this could be useful but the cost is very high, for what I think amounts to a small benefit (if you're reading a doc, chances are you're already running the library in your app).
- due to conflicts, we couldn't inject the scripts in the main window (can't unload JS after it's been loaded, and on DevDocs you never reload the page)
- an alternative would be to inject the scripts in an iframe, but then it's a lot less user-friendly
- it would add significant maintenance overhead (to keep everything working & up-to-date)

Thanks for the PR. Will look into this as soon as I can (ETA 3-4 weeks).

> Is there a way to not show class fields in the nav bar but show them on search?

Yes but I'd prefer all entries have a `type` / are accessible via the sidebar nav. If there are lots of types, we can group things together more aggressively.

For this PR I think we should group all the platform-specific entries together. I.e. a single type for "cpp", "java", etc. so we end up with the same top level types as on http://api.haxe.org/ 

> Or maybe create multiple levels on the navigation? 

This has come up a couple times but for now my position is that it would add too much complexity to the app, for a small payoff.

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I'd prefer we wait until 1.0 is released to keep track of multiple versions, so just change it to 0.7.0.

@Thibaut Thanks for the feedback!

> I'd prefer we wait until 1.0 is released to keep track of multiple versions, so just change it to 0.7.0.

Okay. :+1: 

> Would you mind also including the C++ docs? (change the base URL to https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/master/api_docs/)

I would really prefer to keep them separate so C++ users don't get results for the python api and vice versa. That's why I included the `-py` identifier for the language in the release string, so the C++ api documentation can be e.g. `0.7.0-cc` or `0.7.0-cpp`. That way users will be able to pick exactly what they need, but the different languages would still be grouped together under the general _TensorFlow_ item in the list of available apis.

I haven't included the C++ api yet because I don't use it myself, so it wouldn't get a lot of testing from my own side. But it should not be hard to try out.

Hi there,

first of all thank you for this great plugin. I went through the documentation and tried to follow the guides on https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/wiki/Adding-documentations-to-DevDocs to get the documentation of http://padrinorb.com/ (the doc of the framework is written in rdoc http://www.rubydoc.info/github/padrino/padrino-framework).

A `docs:page padrino --debug` give me the following output

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

and a `thor docs:generate padrino --force --debug` give me the following error:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I can't figure out what's wrong. I tried the bower scrape and remove the `clean_html.rb` as well as the `clean_html.rb` and the scrape command scraped me the whole page => this is something I would expect from my example as well.

Thanks for helping me.

This is because you didn't add the two filters to the scraper. See: https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/blob/17b269d68376991e0e482920e0f4a311efebe747/lib/docs/scrapers/bower.rb#L13

Note that it seems [this](https://github.com/wikimatze/devdocs/blob/134f00b672793210e8cf34a79caa529047aba395/lib/docs/filters/padrino/clean_html.rb#L6) is selecting an element that doesn't exist (I only see a `#main`, not `.main`, in the source), and that you'll need to implement `get_name` / `get_type` / `additional_entries` in your [`EntriesFilter`](https://github.com/wikimatze/devdocs/blob/134f00b672793210e8cf34a79caa529047aba395/lib/docs/filters/padrino/entries.rb).

An inconvenient of using localStorage and IndexedDB is that a browser may delete the data if you haven't visited the website for some time or the computer is running low on storage.

Such unwanted behavior (in this case) may be mitigated implementing an export/import feature:
- The user can export their downloaded documentations into a JSON file, to store as a backup in case the browser deletes local data. The file would include a backup of the localStorage and IndexedDB.
- At later time, the user can an import the backup JSON file via file upload, completely overwriting the localStorage and IndexedDB into the backed-up values and restoring offline documentation access.

As far as I know, the only issue the user might face is being unable to access DevDocs offline in the first place, but I'm hopeful someone could think of a solution to mitigate this issue.
:+1: It would also allow easily transfer documentation to offline computers, where Internet connection is restricted or unavailable due to technical or security reasons.

This text in [Angular's $sce documentation](https://code.angularjs.org/1.4.7/docs/api/ng/service/$sce) (version 1.4.7):

> Note: When enabled (the default), IE<11 in quirks mode is not supported. In this mode, IE<11 allow one to execute arbitrary javascript by the use of the expression() syntax. Refer to learn more about them. 

Does not match this text in the [devdocs $sce documentation](http://devdocs.io/angular/ng/service/%24sce#show-me-an-example-using-sce-.html):

> Note: When enabled (the default), IE to learn more about them.

My guess is that the web scraper misinterpreted the meaning of the encoded open angle bracket in "IE<11" and what looks like a bogus tag in the source HTML. Here's what angular's HTML looks like:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

The "bogus" tag I mentioned is `<http: blogs.msdn.com="" b="" ie="" archive="" 2008="" 10="" 16="" ending-expressions.aspx="">`. It looks like a mangled link. (See the [source](https://github.com/angular/angular.js/blob/v1.4.7/src/ng/sce.js#L417).)

Here is what the HTML from the currently deployed dev docs looks like:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I bet the scraper probably should not interpret `<` as the start of an HTML tag. Maybe it's an upstream bug.

For posterity:

I traced the source of the issue to a probable bug in the [marked](https://github.com/chjj/marked) library, on which angular's documentation build task depends to parse markdown. In my view, the fault is not due to a failure to escape the angle brackets manually in the source documentation. The [markdown dingus](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/dingus), for example, when given the same input escapes the angle brackets as I expect. I'll look into writing a fix to marked.

In Dash.app for OSX, I give most of my documentation simple prefixes so that I can quickly filter out documentation I don't care about and peruse only a specific set of docs I do. At any point during your query you simply type the prefix followed by a `:` and it switches to that doc.

Some prefixes I've setup personally have been:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

When I want to for example search for a function in angular documentation I would type in the following:
`ng:isnumber` and it will only show me search result pages for the documentations that match that prefix (yes multiple documentations can share a similar prefix). I left out the space because on Dash the moment you type the `:` it immediately converts it to a tag and the remaining text entry is treated visually different.

You can already do that if you hit <kbd>Tab</kbd> instead of <kbd>:</kbd>, though it won't search in more than one doc after you hit tab. Abreviations are listed on the [Tips page](http://devdocs.io/help#abbreviations)

As @binaryannie said (thanks), you can do the same in DevDocs by typing a documentation name (or an abbreviation) + <kbd>Tab</kbd>.
For example: <kbd>ror</kbd> + <kbd>Tab</kbd>.

There are several accessibility issues with devdocs which may impair users of assistive technologies such as screen reader users from using devdocs effectively:
- <s>Violations of WCAG colour contrast limits</s>
- There are several areas which could use aria roles could be used to improve the screenreader and keyboard usuability of the site
- Aria live regions would be good to allow screen readers know the documentation pane has updated 

I'd like to have a look at some of the issues above, just a heads up in case other people are working on the same

Hey!

Good to know. There's definitely room for improvement.

> Violations of WCAG colour contrast limits

This is a tricky problem as I find that high contrast UIs don't look great on high quality displays (which already have good contrast). To get the best of both worlds, maybe we could create a separate high-contrast /  "accessibility" color scheme?

I'll probably fix the issues with it in high contrast mode first but the WCAG guidelines are supposed to be followed regardless of the mode. That said most of the application complies with the 4.5 minimum contrast.

@Thibaut is there a particular reason there is a meta tag which disables scaling? Didn't want to just remove it as I presumed it was put there to solve a particular problem.

`<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,initial-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no,shrink-to-fit=no">`

> is there a particular reason there is a meta tag which disables scaling?

The UI breaks when zoomed:

![iphone 5s - iphone 5s ios 9 2 13c75 2016-02-07 09-25-05](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17579/12872877/2babef0c-cd7d-11e5-8dde-25aa98880a3e.png) ![iphone 5s - iphone 5s ios 9 2 13c75 2016-02-07 09-25-17](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17579/12872879/2e9c7100-cd7d-11e5-8ee6-221ed250c618.png)

`user-scalable=no` also removes the 300ms tap/click delay on [Android](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2013/12/300ms-tap-delay-gone-away) and soon [iOS](https://trac.webkit.org/changeset/191072).
It's technically a WCAG failure but considering all the desktop browsers ignore it for the most part and it's very useful for mobile there's no great point in removing it.

Added some aria role attributes and cleaned up the markup here: https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/commit/dd86527da5392e38c76832dd27010e186b0095a5

More than that (live regions, etc.) would require extensive testing. Not something I'm interested in doing at the moment (sorry), so closing this issue. If anyone is interested in pushing this forward, PRs are more than welcome.

I second this suggestion.

DevDocs's format is standard across docs. The two main files are:

http://docs.devdocs.io/lodash/index.json
http://docs.devdocs.io/lodash/db.json

There are some requirements around the structure of HTML files + dependencies on CSS and JS, which I'm happy to try to formalize and make more flexible if there's enough interest in a public format.

This could then lead to an "add your own doc" feature.

If anyone is interested in this, the best way to go would be to make a proof of concept using the existing format and hacking the manifest file (`docs.json`) to make new docs show up in the app. I can then help improve and formalize all this.

Thanks for the PR. We need to find a way to automate the `self.initial_paths` list or this is going to be impossible to maintain.

One way to do it is to fetch the root page via Selenium. It'll run JS on the page, which may reveal all the links we need to follow. Angular works like that: https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/blob/master/lib/docs/scrapers/angular.rb#L33-L38 (to scrape with Selenium you'll need to run `SELENIUM=1 bundle install` and prefix the `thor` commands with `SELENIUM=1`). 

Another way to do it would be to override `root_page_body` (`include StubRootPage`) to fetch the `tree.json` file and turn it into an HTML list.

Fair enough, I'll look into both ways and resend the pull request with whichever seems to work best. 

Thanks for the tool and your time :)
You could also update this PR. Whichever works best for you.

It's easy to add Dojox and Dijit (just remove [this](https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/blob/5de8c37258348821bc70337fa52dba6af6bd4711/lib/docs/scrapers/dojo.rb#L27)). Are there large chunks of Dojox and Dijit we can ignore / aren't useful to most people?

Dojox is the experimental part of dojo, bits of it are useful but for the most part people steer clear because it's difficult to tell what bits are maintained and which bits aren't.

Dijit is dojo's widget library, this is actually heavily used but it's depends on the developer's usage. Most of the projects I'ved worked on for instance, we only used the framework to build our own widgets along with one or two of the more common widgets like the modal dialog.

I would probably ignore dojox completely. in regards to dijit, I think making a subclass of the scraper which only targets dijit would be better so that people could decide if they wanted it like Jquery vs Jquery UI. Let me know what you think I don't mind implementing it.

Proposed workflow
1. Enter [a website](http://ricardo.cc/2013/06/07/react-tutorial-rewritten-in-plain-javascript.html)
2. The extension automatically identifies code snippets and the language they're written in
3. Hover mouse over a function name/module/class etc. to get a short description  
   Like (the scope of the info is to be discussed) "_Returns the first element within the document (using depth-first pre-order traversal of the document's nodes|by first element in document markup and iterating through sequential nodes by order of amount of child nodes) that matches the specified group of selectors._" for `document.QuerySelector`
4. Click to get to [full doc on devdocs.io](http://devdocs.io/dom/document/queryselector)

Benefits
- It complies with the cornerstone of DevDoc's vision: _DevDocs aims to make reading and searching reference documentation fast, easy and enjoyable._
- Could make it faster to understand code, especially when at the early stages of learning a given subject.
  - Would replace the current workflow: ctrl+l -> d -> tab -> [type in query string] -> enter

At the same time I'm not sure if it falls in the "non-full-text search enginge" category.

What do you think?

In the "Contributing Guidelines" under "Requesting new documentation" it states to NOT open a new issue to request documentation, and to instead vote on external site Trello.Then, under the "contributing new documentations" section, it states to "Please open an issue before adding a new documentation".  

I've seen numerous replies on issues in this repo for documentation requests with just 2 links back to the "contributing" guidelines and external site Trello but no clarification on correct procedure for adding documentation.  Does the vote on Trello have to reach a certain amount of votes before documentation can be added?  Is there an "approved documentation to be added" queue on Trello that has to be accepted before new documentation can be added or can anyone submit a PR with new documentation?  On Trello, it says "DevDocs is open source -- the fastest way to see a documentation is to contribute" but I am unsure if documentation can be contributed before it is "voted" on, or can anyone submit a PR with new documentation.  Thank you for your assistance.

> I've seen numerous replies on issues in this repo for documentation requests with just 2 links back to the "contributing" guidelines and external site Trello but no clarification on correct procedure for adding documentation.

The Contributing Guidelines are asking that you open an issue if you're actively working on adding a new documentation, so that multiple people don't work on the same doc at the same time. If you're not working on it (as was the case in all these issues), then you should use Trello. Otherwise we'll end up with as many GitHub issues as we have Trello cards.

I'll remove the sentence that asks to open an issue when working on a doc, to avoid the confusion.

>  Does the vote on Trello have to reach a certain amount of votes before documentation can be added?

No, but the doc should be reasonably popular (i.e. don't submit your personal/just-launched projects until they've gotten some traction).

>  Is there an "approved documentation to be added" queue on Trello that has to be accepted before new documentation can be added?

No, but better check with me first (GitHub issue or email).

Thanks

The Offline docs state:

> Note that loading any page other than [devdocs.io](http://devdocs.io) directly won't work (due to limitations in AppCache).

You could have the following in your appcache manifest:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

Then, when the user tries to navigate to a URI such as http://devdocs.io/css/@charset by typing directly into the URI bar or the browser being launched by an external program, the fallback would be used and devdocs could have code in the normal index page to load the correct data. I assume that devdocs.org is just sending the user the normal page anyway.

The possible gotchas here should just be that if devdocs is trying to load data through AJAX the AJAX request might get the fallback page rather than the requested data—if the user is offline and the AJAX request should have failed anyway.

Supporting launching directly to a particular documentation page when in offline mode would make the offline experience even more seemless than it already is.

Another though, if AJAX-fetched resources are only at certain namespaces anyway, would be to do the following:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

If I’m understanding how appcache works correctly, this would make most users launching to a particular URI fetch it directly from appcache rather than trying to load it directly from the website first. When the browser is not able to access the Internet, this would eliminate a timeout in trying to fetch the documentation URI from the browser. When the browser is able to access the internet, this will prevent the browser from making a (small) number of superfluous requests to the server.

Thoughts?

Thanks for investigating this.

I can't enable app cache beyond the root page because (1) each page would end up in the cache, leading to an ever increasing cache (app cache constraint), and (2) the app runs in different modes when loading from the root vs. another page (so that external links to docs that the user hasn't yet enabled still work).

You can, however, load and search any page when offline like this:
http://devdocs.io/#/css/@charset
http://devdocs.io/#q=test

> (1) each page would end up in the cache, leading to an ever increasing cache (app cache constraint)

As long as the document you use for the fallback entry doesn’t have a `manifest` attribute, and it doesn’t now, then the cache shouldn’t arbitrarily increase in size.

> (2) the app runs in different modes when loading from the root vs. another page (so that external links to docs that the user hasn't yet enabled still work).

If you look at the [appcache fetch algorithm](http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/browsers.html#changesToNetworkingModel), you’ll see that putting a URI namespace in the fallback section attempts to access the internet before loading the fallback entry. If `/` is listed as a namespace which should get the fallback document when the internet is inaccessible, that should not prevent attempts to load resources from online-only docsets. It just provides a way to serve to the user your special directly-linked mode page without the user having to be connected to the internet.

> You can, however, load and search any page when offline like this:
> http://devdocs.io/#/css/@charset
> http://devdocs.io/#q=test

Then why redirect the user to non-hash URIs? If the user browsed the whole site through hash URIs in the first place, this whole issue would be skirted ;-). The user should not need to manually edit bookmark URIs, for example, or have to edit the URIs of about restored tabs.

My point is that appcache has the capability to enable direct navigation while the user is offline even with your current URI scheme. Why not take advantage of it?

> If you look at the appcache fetch algorithm, you’ll see that putting a URI namespace in the fallback section attempts to access the internet before loading the fallback entry. If / is listed as a namespace which should get the fallback document when the internet is inaccessible, that should not prevent attempts to load resources from online-only docsets.

TIL, thanks. a0ea89ff45a0ff73e5eab980de119982d1ae2b21

> Then why redirect the user to non-hash URIs?

Because http://devdocs.io/css/@charset is guaranteed to show you the doc even if you haven't enabled it (e.g. you clicked a link on StackOverflow). This works by comparing the request path with the "docs" cookie on the server, and returning a different page (single doc vs. full app) depending on if the doc is enabled or not.

http://devdocs.io/#/css/@charset, on the other hand, will fail if the doc is disabled, since the `#hash` part of the URL isn't sent to the server, and the root path will only load docs that you've enabled (for performance reasons — DevDocs has 100k entries, the app would be much slower if it loaded all of them all the time).

> TIL, thanks. a0ea89f

Thanks, that appears to work!

> http://devdocs.io/#/css/@charset, on the other hand, will fail if the doc is disabled

Ah, so right now it will not try to dynamically load the CSS docset when it sees `css` in the hash.

I was quite excited finding this repository and it even includes a JSON API as concluded here: https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/issues/133 

Now that this project has a JSON-API; I suggest we use it to not only integrate into IDE's but possibly into a Mobile App where you can use a phone and/or tablet (which this on tablets would be awesome to use this with) would be very useful to have. I see that you have a mobile version which you can download offline docs and it is wonderfully made and designed as stated in the goals of the repository: "...maintain a clean and readable user interface; be fully functional offline; support full keyboard navigation;". Though I want to take these goals a step further by introducing the idea for a mobile app. I think introducing a native mobile app in will take what all the contributors have achieved in meeting the goals and take it a step further by "...maintain[ing] a clean and readable user interface..." by adhering to the design standards of the apps ecosystem, "...be fully functional offline..." by ushering the app into a native ecosystem to their respective platform, "support full keyboard navigation" by coming up with ways to make a efficient UX by not just a keyboard but a touch interface.

Of coarse I would love for one defined user interface though there are standards to those interfaces which the users of mobile devices are accustomed to. Developers of cross platform apps sometimes tend to try to create a different UX and UI experience based on the platform they are developing for. The reason for this is because even though there is a lot more effort(and money) into redesigning an app for each platform. Even though the statement is vague that the project's goals are to "...maintain a clean and readable user interface..." and "...support full keyboard support..." I would think of asking myself what defines a clean user interface?. Also, why is it not stated to provide "...support for fully touch interfaces..."? It means different things to different people of a clean interface because one could say Google's "Material Design Standards" are clean when in an iPhone in the users eyes would maybe say "iPhone's Design Standards" for apps provide a cleaner user interface. One could argue that we don't want to create a complexity through making an interface for each platform and we must keep consistency for the sake for the project. Though in another light, we are only making small tweaks. As far as I know both Android and IOS have the commonly used "sliding sidebar" and their are quite a good amount of similarities in terms of design and user interface that can be implemented in both apps. But it would probably be a good idea to implement them in the ecosystem that the users are used to in which gives a highly available experience. Please discuss this and even argue on my points, I would like to see another perspective other than mine. 

Speaking of a highly available experience, another goal of the project is to "...be fully functional offline...". And their is no better way to do that than ushering a native experience for the project. The project indeed has downloadable offline docs and caching. Though bringing a native experience is far more accessible than caching. Caching requires the user to access the website and yes so does downloading the app needs the internet to download from the apps native app store. Though I want to leave that open for discussion since both benefits seem to equal each other.

So I believe their is potential for devdocs.io to move into the mobile app sphere. Even though I think its important rather to support more languages, frameworks, and libraries into the project; it still is an extra thing we can keep in mind as we continue to move forward with it. I have worked with Android Development myself and feel this would be something I would want on my Samsung Note 10.1 2014 edition tablet to use for quick reference with one less browser window open on my desktop. I would also like to hear what others think they can use this for. Please feel free to correct me on anything I said regarding any technical and grammatical related matters(I'm not perfect and we all make mistakes). I would love to work on something like this since I am a Junior in college and need more projects under my belt as well. Thanks for reading! I look forward to discussing with you all upon these matters.

(If I violated the CONTRIBUTION guidelines please let me know. I did read the Feature Request section before posting this but again I may have misunderstood the context of it.)

Thanks for the write-up.

DevDocs doesn't have an API yet. It only makes certain files (used by the web app for the search) publicly available. You're free to use those to make your own app.

I have no interest in making a native app, sorry. I don't have the time (DevDocs is just a side project of mine), nor feel that this is in the spirit of the project (even though I can see the use case). The web app has a mobile-optimized version; you can add a shortcut to it on your homescreen and get most of the functionality that a native app would provide (PRs that improve the UI are welcome).

I have no objections to anyone making a native version of DevDocs, though, so long as you credit DevDocs for the data and use a different name (see the [copyright section of the README](https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs#copyright--license)). On the contrary, I'd be happy to promote it on devdocs.io if it's well made.
