Each doc highlights deprecated functions differently. I'd rather leave it to them to do the job than maintain "deprecated" lists in DevDocs, sorry.
Who says you have to maintain it?  We already have perfectly good parsers that can be modified to figure it out for us, don't we?

> that can be modified to figure it out for us

This code will need to be written and maintained across docs and updates.

I don't want to make DevDocs more time-consuming to maintain unless there is a significant benefit to be had by most users at the end. Since most docs like MDN already do a good job of highlighting deprecated functions (MDN puts a big red banner at the top), I don't think the benefit of implementing such a feature in DevDocs will be useful to most users, sorry.

This isn't about _highlighting_ deprecated functions; this is about the exact _opposite_.  Taking some noise out of the signal, so I don't have to dodge descriptions of deprecated HTML attributes whenever I'm doing web dev.

That doesn't change the fact that one has to know what these functions are in order to hide them. 

If you care strongly about this, feel free to fork the repo and run the app locally.

If I or someone else were to actually implement this (even for just one set of docs, on a provisional/prototypical basis) in a way that doesn't need maintenance (e.g. parsing the page for `Deprecated` or similar), would you consider merging it in?

Sorry but no. There will inevitably be a maintenance cost, and I don't want to clutter the codebase with  half-implemented/experimental features.

In any case, I disagree that hiding deprecated functions would be useful to most users. If we make it a user setting (which the UI currently doesn't support), people will forget that they enabled it and be confused when they search a function that has recently been deprecated and no results show up.

Searching for pushState produces no results.

There's a DOM History node (http://devdocs.io/dom/history) and from there you can see pushState documented but the function itself is not in the index.
I'll fix this up in a future update.

If you don't have time to work on it and you think you could sketch out the
basic approach to fixing it here I would be happy to try to fix it myself.

Hey guys,
There isn't much I can do here. DevDocs tries to use IndexedDB when it's available, otherwise it shows the error page. There's no "user-agent sniffing" going on.
This means that Android's embedded browser likely isn't the same as Chrome/Firefox for Android, and doesn't support IndexedDB at this time.
Hopefully Google will fix that in a future version of Android.

You can add old Android support with _IndexedDB polyfill over WebSQL_ https://github.com/axemclion/IndexedDBShim, https://www.npmjs.com/package/cordova-plugin-indexeddb-async. Keep in mind WebSQL is dropped from spec.

Based on [caniuse...sql-storage.json#L214](https://github.com/Fyrd/caniuse/blob/1c13358ba79fa3ce1453be4afe1f13089126888b/features-json/sql-storage.json#L214) seems supported since Android 2.1, except:

> Reported to not be supported on the Samsung-based Android 4.

If you're using the app from the play store, please uninstall it. It's made by someone who is using (and profiting from) the name DevDocs without permission. If you install the app via Chrome (visit [devdocs.io](http://devdocs.io) and select "Add to home screen"), the offline mode will work fine and there'll be no ads.

> You can add old Android support with IndexedDB polyfill over WebSQL

I'd rather not import a large and complex dependency like this (which means bugs and extra maintenance), when most browsers support IndexedDB already.

@Thibaut, thanks for suggestion! I agree with on avoiding outdated frameworks, dropped specs, etc.

I was just wondering if there are any plans to package this app as a desktop app using something like NW.js? I would imagine you wouldn't need to implement any of the server component in the application as it could just communicate with the http://devdocs.io/ "api" directly.

See #39.

I'm not against the idea but have no interest in working on this myself. The web app is fully functional offline so I don't see much benefit to a desktop app, with the exception of a task/menu bar app that brings up the web app.

>  I would imagine you wouldn't need to implement any of the server component in the application as it could just communicate with the http://devdocs.io/ "api" directly. 

DevDocs doesn't have an API. The search is done entirely in the browser. That's why it's fast no matter how slow your internet connection is :)

The web app gets metadata to use for the search (name/path of functions, etc.), then loads the pages from the CDN (or IndexedDB, if you've downloaded the doc for offline access).

Closing this since I have no intention of making a desktop app at this time. If someone wants to, and there is something I can do to help, feel free to open a new issue or email the [mailing list](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/devdocs).

Hey!

Sorry for the late reply.

This was a side-effect of fixing #209. When pinning the tab and restarting the browser, DevDocs used to launch in "single doc" mode unless the last URL was the root URL. Me and others found it annoying to have to press `Esc` twice to go back to "all docs" mode, so I made it so the app always boots in that mode for docs that have been enabled.

Tomorrow I will make it so the search scope is automatically set when the app is launched from a doc URL, which should resolve this issue (command+enter will then focus a doc until you press `Esc`).

Even after blurring the search box, I can't scroll using the up/down arrow keys. Usually focus starts on the body and I have to hit some shortcut (like `/`) to focus the search/nav. Like this I can't even unfocus to do the native up/down thing.

I'm sure the up/down functionality is by design, but I consider the breaking of the scrolling a bug.

You can use `alt+up/down` and `space/shift+space` to scroll (press `?` to see all shortcuts). DevDocs would become hard to use IMO if you had to constantly switch back & forth between focusing & blurring the search field to activate different keyboard shortcuts.

Search is the app's primary function; I don't want people to have to think twice (is the search field focused or not) before typing or hitting the arrow keys. To make things predictable, `up` & `down` always navigate the sidebar.

I might add a user setting to swap the behavior of `up/down` and `alt+up/down`, but I don't consider this a bug, sorry.

Thanks again for your contribution & hard work. This is adding a lot of complexity for one set of docs, which makes it harder / more time-consuming for me to maintain things in the future. I'd like to explore ways we can get simplify this before moving forward (unfortunately Drupal has the worst URLs of any docs I've ever seen, by a long margin :/).

Questions & comments:
1. Why did you need the `p.gsub! /\./, '_'` and `p.gsub /__/, '..'` in `fixUri`? (can you provide examples/stacktraces where it failed?)
2. If we add an option to run each URL/path through `URI.decode_www_form` for a given scraper, we should be able to get rid of `fixUri` and the monkey patches in `NormalizePathsFilter`, `InternalUrlsFilter` and `EntriesFilter`. I'll look into that when I have time.
3. Each entry should have a type (never `nil`, unless the doc has no types at all), otherwise they don't appear in the sidebar. Guides &co can be grouped together or skipped (API stuff is more important).
4. Skip all the changelog stuff ("Updates from 6.x to 7.x"). The doc is clocking at 50MB, we should try to trim down the fat as much as possible (more entries == less useful search, bigger size == more likely offline storage will exceed the browser's quota).
5. I'd prefer we remove all the `/7`, e.g., instead of scrapping https://api.drupal.org/api/drupal/includes!form.inc/function/batch_get/7 we should scrape https://api.drupal.org/api/drupal/includes!form.inc/function/batch_get. We could do that using `fix_urls` similarly to [here](https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/blob/744d7caa8a504998a14868bf1bb6db416e632ce3/lib/docs/scrapers/laravel.rb#L35).
6. Please remove `public/docs/docs.json` from the commit.

3. I removed a lot of these skipping updates, test, etc. For the remaining, even if they won't appear in the sidebar still are searchable. Lot of these functions are hook implementations of the core modules.

Hi, I'm trying to make the drupal documentation. One problem that I found is that at api.drupal.org there are several paged tables. For example at the starting point that I choose: https://api.drupal.org/api/drupal/groups
The pager links are not followed (since the uri is the same, only the query parameters change)
Is there a way to force fetching these links and merge the pages into one (with some manual preprocessing)? like https://api.drupal.org/api/drupal/groups and https://api.drupal.org/api/drupal/groups?object_name=&summary=&page=1 into groups
Let me know, other way I can create a local copy of the api.drupal.org website and modify the tables to show all the results (but it will need a real good howto to reproduce it)

Regards

Hi

Scraping the same path twice with different query params isn't supported, sorry. The location of the file and a bunch of other things are entirely based on the path, and it would be quite difficult to change that.

What you could do instead is manually add the URLs on page 2 to your scraper's `initial_paths`, like [here](https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/blob/0a09c8904e88692b13f877f8b797bf6f9a9105c2/lib/docs/scrapers/requirejs.rb#L8-L16). It's a bit harder to maintain (you have to manually hard-code the paths), but will achieve the same effect as visiting the page with the scraper.

Hope this helps. Closing this issue as it's not really an issue.

Devdocs kept forgetting about my selected documentations and reverting to the default ones, even though it would still have the offline data around in IndexedDB. Turns out this preference is stored in a cookie, and I have set up my browser to agressively forget cookies (every time I close the browser).

Would it be possible to store the preferences in IndexedDB instead, perhaps only if user has enabled offline?

Using localStorage instead of a cookie would be a solution, but I suspect we should consider localStorage to be as volatile as cookies, since localStorage doesn't ask for user permission to store data.

This isn't possible, sorry. The server needs to know which docs you've selected in order to render the app cache manifest: http://devdocs.io/manifest.appcache
You could whitelist cookies on `devdocs.io` instead.

I'm really happy to see a dark mode; but honestly, it can be kind of hard to read; and a lot of the colours don't have quite enough contrast.

Have you considered using the ‘[Solarized](http://ethanschoonover.com/solarized)’ colour-scheme? It's very popular, and extremely readable in both light _and_ dark mode. (In fact, that's precisely what it was designed to do: choose colours with scientifically-backed contrast levels between each colour and both the light and dark backgrounds.)

Hell, if I had my way, I'd love to see both the light _and_ dark modes changed to adhere to Solarized. :P

Other things worth noting: the section-headers could do with a little more contrast, but it's not horrible; and the table-border lines are almost invisible in dark-mode.

That said, I'd still love to see a switch to Solarized; but that's probably a bit subjective of me. :P

When searching for a JavaScript method, like Array.join, I typically type: 

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

The abbreviation `js` is extended to one of the many JS libraries, frameworks and tools, as they are an exact match to `js`, yet JavaScript does not. Similarly, typing `md`, a very common abbreviation for Markdown, rarely lists Markdown, depending on which modules are enabled. For me, it shows the PHP’s md5 function. A third example would be Sass’ file extension `scss`.

Perhaps a set of common abbreviations could be implemented as aliases that is searched through prior to the global fuzzy search. Being able to customise those could also be a great improvement.

For now, I’ll just teach myself to use `jsc` or something because I’m not giving up on this brilliant tool.

On Firefox, you can add an option to Install a Web-app with the [Web App Manifest](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/Apps/Build/Manifest#Requirements_for_generic_Open_Web_Apps).

It could basically work like this:
![screen shot 2015-04-08 at 11 17 26](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1769951/7042276/f1342272-dde0-11e4-9171-dfc07b9ba269.png)

Once you click the 'Install' link, the browser will ask for confirmation, and if confirmed by the user, it will Install the Web-app as a standalone app on the OS. Basically the same as a Fluid app, but without actually needing any external tool.

#### Introduction

I've been trying to nail down the steps for this for a few days now and I finally got it!
#### Steps
1. Enable **Node.js** and at least one other language.
2. In the search box...
   1. Type `node<TAB>` to enable the filter.
   2. Type `unlink<ENTER>` to select the **fs.unlink** article.
      
      > _This will open the unlink article, and rewrite the URL to `/node/fs#fs_fs_unlink_path_callback`._
3. Reload the page.
   
   > _For me, this happens when my previous tabs are re-opened the next day from their previous-day state._
#### Results

What happens is that the site loads in the `/node` folder and from that point on is "rooted" to the **Node.js** documentation. There's no clear way to get back to other languages outside of clicking the **DevDocs** link or manually going to the site root.

To me, if the site is rewriting the URL to add the new documentation path, reloading should return it to the state it was in when it got rewritten rather than the "rooted" state that it loads in now. That is, the search box should contain the filter and the full tree should be displayed with the appropriate documentation article selected.
#### Aside

DevDocs is a fantastic idea that has been very well executed. It is a permanently-open tab for me, at work. This issue is absolutely a minor inconvenience, but I wanted to report it as I didn't see it in the list of open issues. Thanks for creating this awesome tool!

Thanks for the detailed issue.

This is the intended behavior (there is a banner at the bottom of the page that tells you when the app is in "single doc" mode). It's required because of how DevDocs work (to keep things fast, only the docs the user has selected are loaded in memory), as well as limitations in the AppCache API (which is only reliable on the root path).

To go from "single doc" mode to "full app" mode you can also press `escape` twice.
I see, thanks for the response! Maybe to improve the discoverability of that shortcut, it could be parenthetically included in that bottom banner?
Good idea. I'll add this next week-end.

The base font color lightness is just _ever-so-slightly_ too dark and **doesn't provide enough contrast** to the background, IMO.  It makes reading the text somewhat of a chore and turns me off of the otherwise great-looking new dark theme and to me, **that makes it a bug.**

And since I thought it was a problem, **I took a shot at finding a solution.**, I did a little testing and came up with this **_tiny**_ adjustment below (pull request incoming).  Original HEX values temporarily **converted to HSL to isolate the issue source** using devtools and show differences easily.  

**Example:**

<S_CODE_TOKEN>
## Old

> color: hsl(48, 3%, 70%);
>     = #B4B3AF
## Goldilocks-approved

> color: hsl(48, 3%, **90%**);
>     = **#E6E6E5**

When enough documentations are stored offline, so that the sqlite file reaches about 50 MB, the web app is not able to access it anymore. The interface is fully functional, but opening the Offline tab results in the message

> Oops, the database failed to load.

This also prevents the user from resetting the app.
After deleting the storage files in `[Profile_directory]/storage/default`, the app is fully functional again.
The web app was created using Firefox Developer Edition 37.0a2, however the web version on the same browser has no such size limitation.
Thanks for the bug report. I'll look into this as soon as I can.

Unfortunately there's no way to programmatically detect what the size limitation is, and once the quota is reached the database is locked and can't be opened anymore (at least in Firefox).

As a work-around I made it so the database is automatically deleted when the quota is reached, with a notification explaining why.

Hi. I am a developer of [Zeal](/zealdocs/zeal) offline documentation browser. I would like to add support for DevDocs.io as another source of documentation in addition to Dash docsets. Zeal has it's own search capabilities, so it wouldn't require any API support.

My questions are:
1. Is it fine to download `index.json` and `db.json` from maxcdn-docs.devdocs.io in Zeal?
2. Where is the proper place to obtain a list of all DevDocs documentation? I've seen [that file](http://maxcdn.devdocs.io/assets/docs-6e0f33be46ca623e17d32c7aeb62ec31.js), but I cannot find `docs.json` file, which is referenced in some places.

Hi @trollixx 

Glad to hear you're looking to make DevDocs's documentation available in Zeal.

>  Is it fine to download `index.json` and `db.json` from maxcdn-docs.devdocs.io in Zeal?

Yes, but:
- I never purge the cache on that CDN, so something like `maxcdn-docs.devdocs.io/css/index.json` is not guaranteed to be up-to-date. To get the correct version you need to append the `mtime` of that particular doc (defined in `docs.json`) as a query param (e.g. `maxcdn-docs.devdocs.io/css/index.json?1420139789`).
- I can't guarantee that I won't make breaking changes to the data format of the these files, or their location. When I do, I'll try to remember to let you know about it.
- Please attribute each document to `devdocs.io` in a way that your users will notice. It takes a lot of work to maintain these docs / metadata.

> Where is the proper place to obtain a list of all DevDocs documentation?

Currently the `docs.json` file doesn't have a unique URL (it gets deployed with a different filename every time it changes, like the other assets). I'll make `devdocs.io/docs.json` redirect to the most recent version for you this week-end. However, please make sure Zeal doesn't request that file too often (on boot is ok), since it goes through my server — not the CDN.

> I'll let you know, when I start working on such feature.

Actually, not having a maximum width is much _worse_ for usability, because text gets very difficult to read when it gets too wide (this is fact, not opinion). This is why practically every well designed site on the Internet has a maximum width, such as the one you're using right now, and several other developer-related sites you may be familiar with:

http://stackexchange.com
http://developer.mozilla.org

For anyone who actually understands and cares about usability, you can use these styles with Stylish (an extension for Safari, Chrome, and Firefox) to make the site usable in a maximized browser window. This constrains the width to 1280px total, and centers it. Adjust the width to your liking. If you don't want it centered, you can drop the `margin: 0 auto` line from `._app`.

@symmetriq I agree with you but since I mostly use DevDocs on a 1280x800 display I rarely get that problem, and too many people were complaining about the fixed width. In the redesign I'll try to implement a customizable width. Glad you at least got it fixed for you using a custom style.
@Thibaut No problem. [Here's a suggestion](https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/issues/128#issuecomment-60542623) for a simple toggle that lets people view DevDocs the way they want.

The overall UI should be constrained to a reasonable maximum width. On a 27" iMac (2560px width), in a maximized browser window, DevDocs stretches to fill the entire width, making it very difficult to read.

Check out what sites like GitHub or Twitter do when the window is very wide. It's common practise to constrain the main body width when you only have one main content area. GitHub's content area, for example, is 980px wide. I think that would be a reasonable maximum for the DevDocs content area (not counting the sidebar).

Usually I'd just resize my browser window, but I'm currently using a project management web app that actually makes use of the width (it has a large table view with many columns), and DevDocs is just another tab in that window (I keep it pinned in Chrome so it's always ready).

![screen shot 2014-10-07 at 13 17 22](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/102235/4548633/96c3fb42-4e56-11e4-9643-fcfc3205c032.png)

Here's what it looks like with one extra CSS rule:

`._content { max-width: 980px }`

Ideally the entire UI (navbar, sidebar and content) would be centered, but this is the simplest fix for now.

![screen shot 2014-10-07 at 13 28 03](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/102235/4548820/325f5762-4e58-11e4-8993-54aaf4d3ecb2.png)

I brought up the possibility of having the documentation for Bookshelf.js on DevDocs as well for easy reference (tgriesser/bookshelf#455), and the issue was brought up that the DevDocs data is apparently not in a structured format - which I'd say is a fairly good point.

It would probably be a good idea to support reading Dash DocSets (if not using them for storage entirely, insofar that is feasible). This would not only allow for the use of appropriately-licensed third-party Dash sets, but would also make it easier for a project developer to submit their _own_ documentation in a structured format, rather than having to rely on a scraper (which would require maintenance when the source documentation format is changed for any reason).

The Dash format [doesn't seem to be too complicated](https://github.com/exlee/d3-dash-gen/blob/master/parse.ls), apparently it's just SQLite with XML and regular HTML/CSS/JS.

Hi Sven

I agree a structured format and/or DocSet support would be great but unfortunately this isn't how DevDocs work. With DevDocs I decided to use HTML fragments embedded in the page rather than loading the entire original documents in an iframe (à la Dash). This makes the app faster (no external resources to load) and allows a consistent styling across documentations — which in my opinion help provide a better user experience — but also makes it impossible for DevDocs to support the DocSet format.

I agree this isn't great to encourage user contributions but that's a decision I made early on and can't revisit now, because the entire app is built around it (see some details about this in the [README](https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs#app)).

Now, the idea of a structured format / format spec is one that I've had for some time. There are a couple documentations I'd like to add in the coming weeks but then I'll likely switch my focus to new features like this one. Your ideas are welcome.

In the meantime if you can find me 16x16 and 32x32 icons for bookshelf.js and knex.js I'd be happy to add both documentations to DevDocs. :)

Hmm, perhaps it would be an idea to simply have a generic DocSet-to-HTML-fragment conversion script? Basically, it doesn't necessarily have to be _served_ as a DocSet, as long as you'd be able to use it as an input format of some sort. Regardless of what DevDocs uses internally, you'd still have the benefit of easier / more streamlined maintenance.

Unfortunately the Java docs can't be modified/redistributed:

> This software and related documentation are provided under a license agreement containing restrictions on use and disclosure and are protected by intellectual property laws. Except as expressly permitted in your license agreement or allowed by law, you may not use, copy, reproduce, translate, broadcast, modify, license, transmit, distribute, exhibit, perform, publish, or display any part, in any form, or by any means.

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/legal/cpyr.html

Huh? 

>  Except as expressly permitted in your license agreement

Redistribution and modification _is [expressly permitted in the license](http://openjdk.java.net/legal/gplv2+ce.html)_.

The linked document is nothing but a general Oracle statement regarding all their products saying that use of the product is limited to whatever license it is released under. As the JDK and accompanying API documentation are released under an open source license, redistribution is permitted.

Hi, I'm trying to implement the Haskell Library documentation in devdocs but I can't seem to links to anchor tags working.

I'm tryin to make a Haskell docset, and the Haskell documentation is ridden of anchor tags.

My guess is that devdocs expects identifiers to be `id`'s on element, while in the 
Haskell documentation, they are implemented as `name`'s on `<a>` tags (which is also valid html).

While testing this I also found the solution: add an id to each anchor tag with a `name` on it. Change: .. to: .. This seems to work but it still think it would be nice if `name` tags work out of the box in devdocs.

Always using `id` is simpler and prevents conflicts. As you found out it's easy to rename the `name` attributes and move them around (the element with the `id` attribute is highlighted in DevDocs when opening the associated entry).

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

I think there's no need to restrict the sublevel depth to two.

Thanks for reporting this. The reason why going to `http://devdocs.io/lodash/` doesn't load all docs is to get around some HTML5 appCache peculiarities and so that the page can be rendered even when the user has disabled the doc in question.

@benjamin-thomas Weird. There is no shortcut mapped to `Alt+Space`, only `Space` and `Shift+Space`.
I'm sorry, I actually press <kbd>AltGr</kbd> + <kbd>Space</kbd> to get an underscore, and keypress detection seems to be problematic for this modifier key (or at least clunky) in most browsers.

@benjamin-thomas This means none of the `ctrlKey`, `metaKey`, `altKey` and `shiftKey` modifiers are `true` when the `AltGr+Space` keydown event comes in, so it's handled as a normal `Space` event.

On Windows 8.1 in Chrome, Firefox and IE (all edge stable versions), its not possible to use devdocs without a mouse.

For example, when landing on http://devdocs.io:
1. Search box becomes focused
2. Type in something like 'HTMLAudio' - 'HTMLAudioElement' will be the lone selected item in the search list
3. Press Enter/Return to make your selection
4. Right-side pane will load up the article for HTMLAudioElement, and search box remains selected.

Now, pressing tab while the search box is selected does nothing.

Pressing escape (with the expected behavior of de-selecting the search box) ends up clearing the search term and navigating away from the HTMLAudioElement article.

The net effect is that it's not possible to click on any of the links in the right pane without the mouse.

This is the intended behavior. You can use `space` / `shift+space` or `alt+up/down` to scroll the page. This, combined with the arrows keys to navigate the sidebar, should allow you to browse all of DevDocs's content without using your mouse.

I agree tab-navigation could also be useful, though. I'll try to re-enable that over the week-end.

(see all the shortcuts [here](http://devdocs.io/help))

Thank you. Being able to focus/"click" links on the right pane without clearing the search term would make the site compatible with [vimperator](http://www.vimperator.org/) and I suspect other accessibility software.

I had forgotten that `tab` is used to activate the "single doc" search (e.g. type "html" then `tab`). This means I have to capture the `tab` key when the search input is focused, and when it's not, focus always ends up on the search field because it's the first "focusable" element on the page. 

As a workaround I've implemented `alt+tab` to focus the first link in the right pane. You can then continue hitting `tab` (or `alt+tab` in wekbit) to focus the other links (the links in the sidebar can be focus with the arrow keys).
@Thibaut `alt-tab` is ubiquitously reserved by window managers for switching between windows - perhaps `alt+rarr` instead?

OpenSearch (with suggestions) would allow users to use devdocs as search provider in their web browser's native search box.

This would eliminate the need for keeping the site open on a new tab, or running the app. I already have a ton of tabs open for work, and I already have my screen real estate allocated to my code editor, the browser, Firebug, ssh terminal, and FTP.  Even on a dual-head machine, yet another application open is cumbersome.

The open search suggestions could mimic the search results shown in the left-hand panel of the site, so I have the documentation always available without adding another persistent application or tab to my workspace.

Implementation is extremely easy and lightweight, here is a brief overview: http://perishablepress.com/custom-opensearch-functionality-for-your-website/

Basically, you only would have to add an XML document to the root, and a single line of code to the page's head.

DevDocs already supports OpenSearch: (though not suggestions)
http://devdocs.io/help
http://devdocs.io/opensearch.xml

The help page lists a few `Cmd` key combinations, in particular `Cmd + ←` and `Cmd + →` for navigating back and forth in history. On Windows these combinations become `Ctrl + ←` respectively `Ctrl + →`, which is highly problematic because that exact behaviour is already mapped to `Alt + ←` respectively `Alt + →`. Meanwhile, the `Ctrl` combinations have a different behaviour: to jump the cursor a full word left or right.

I haven't tested how GNU/Linux compares.

I suggest that, for Windows, the back/forth navigation shortcuts, being first-class citizens, be completely dropped. Failing that, that they be rebound to `Alt` to avoid the above confusion.

`Ctrl + Enter` (`Cmd + Enter`) does not currently interfere with anything so doesn't need special handling.

As an aside, and as a much more innocent issue, I would expect the behaviour mapped to `Alt + ↓`, `Alt + ↑` for `↓`, `↑` and `↓`, `↑` for `Ctrl + ↓`, `Ctrl + ↑`, the rationale being that the default behaviour of `↓`, `↑` is incremental scrolling and I would expect to normally have far more need of that than navigating up/down the list of items.
Thanks. I'll investigate this over the week-end.

Could you remove your other commits so I can merge the `docs:verify` task?

I agree it's a good idea, although not all links should be fixed. The ones you mentioned, for example, haven't been written on MDN yet (e.g. [font-variant-alternates](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-variant-alternates)), so it's normal and expected that these links end up broken on DevDocs. I don't want to skip these URLs because we wouldn't notice it if they get written on MDN, and there is little difference in getting a 404 on DevDocs vs. MDN.

  - `spl/exception`: No result.
  - `spl exception`, type: Not possible. Space is ignored.
  - `spl exception`, paste: No result.
  - `splexception`: No result.

It seems that various special characters are not interpreted as expected by the fuzzy search, in addition to any encoding issues there may also be in place. I would expect:
- `/` to be treated as a literal or ignored by search.
- Spaces to be consistently stripped or allowed and possibly ignored by search.
- Query and provider arguments consistently translated to valid search terms. To this end, `%20` should probably be treated as literal space.

I have no personal experience with longest common subsequence matching but I can see the rationale in ignoring spaces. However, it seems to me that a better approach would be to ignore occurrences of spaces in the search term instead of simply stripping them during input.

Thanks for the bug report. I'll look into this over the week-end.

@commonquail The "type" pages such as [SPL/Exceptions](http://devdocs.io/php-spl-exceptions/) aren't part of the search index (the doc also needs to be enabled for results to appear). Thanks for investigating the issue, though; this is very useful.

When I look up, say, exceptions, it's usually because I don't know if the core library includes a fitting one already or which one that would be. In that situation I can't search directly for a _listing_ of exceptions but instead have to rely on the `Alt + r` shortcut from a particular result I know exists (which is nice for what it is but extra work for my poor, lazy fingers). A scoped search for `exception[s]` doesn't produce useful results either; far too many or too little.

tl;dr: I'd _really_ like that but I can understand if it isn't possible.

Addendum: A possible alternative interpretation of space using the provider or the query parameter could be to delimit a search scope.

@commonquail I've opened [a new issue](https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/issues/55) for adding the _type_ pages to the search index. I understand the use case but this isn't straightforward to implement.

Thanks for the bug report. These pages don't exist on the source site (MDN) so we unfortunately can't do much about it.

I don't want to add exceptions for isolated URLs like these because it makes the scrapers harder to maintain.

Every link in the PHP docs is treated as an external link, regardless of whether the article linked to exists within the DevDocs library or not.  This may be due to the fact that PHP's site is geographically distributed with help from subdomains, so a link to www.php.net/something might redirect to us2.php.net/something - presumably to assist with load balancing.  If the subdomain changes between the request and the links, the scraper or processor may not properly detect that the links actually go to the same content, despite having a different domain, and treat them as external.

This isn't a major inconvenience as I can either click the link and continue on the upstream site, or I can remember that the PHP links aren't properly handled and find the article I want via search.  Still, it's less convenient and breaks the usage flow, so it would be nice if it was fixed.  Had I the time, I'd probably attempt to write the patch myself.

Unfortunately this is the intended behavior and not something that can be easily fixed. The PHP documentation uses URLs which aren't well organized and with more than 10,000 files, it's hardly possible to categorize them in advance (I [tried](https://github.com/Thibaut/devdocs/blob/f5eb5479000f7eb8580a26b72546e2e55451b7d2/lib/docs/scrapers/php.rb)), which the current implementation requires in order to update each page's links.

I'll compile some useful notes here:

What is a manifest? https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/Apps/Developing/Manifest?redirectlocale=en-US&redirectslug=Web%2FApps%2FManifest

To validate a manifest, use this website: https://marketplace.firefox.com/developers/validator

There is also an API you can use to validate a manifest: http://firefox-marketplace-api.readthedocs.org/en/latest/ -- could be a nice build step

For hosting on the Firefox Marketplace, when you submit an application that is a hosted app, you need to submit the URL to your manifest.webapp
Do you have an icon that is at least 128 x 128 pixels?

Try the following:

`navigator.mozApps.getInstalled()`
which returns an object with some fields, the one we're interested in is `result`

`result[0].manifest.version` is the version of the latest manifest.

If the manifest ever changes in the future, you can do the following check from your JS:

<S_CODE_TOKEN>

But you don't need to worry about this until you need to update the manifest
When a webapp has not been installed, `getInstalled()` returns a `results` set of `[]`

When looking at documentation from different sources it's difficult to tell at a glance which source you're looking at. For example, when looking up `event.preventDefault` you'll get a result for DOM and jQuery. When reading the documentation, there is no visual difference between the two since they're styled the same, except for the icons in the results sidebar.

I recommend adding some sort of color difference for different sources, within the documentation pages. For instance, a blue header with the jQuery logo for jQuery vs. a green header with the DOM logo for MDN DOM documentation. It'll make it very easy to tell at a glance which source you're reading from.

Can you allow scrolling the right hand side, where the documentation is shown, with the up/down arrow keys, if focus is on the right hand side?

Right now, no matter where focus is in the app, the up/down arrow keys change the selected item in the sidebar.

Not all users have multi-touch trackpads, and if they don't they are forced to use the browser rendered scrollbar to scroll the right hand panel up/down.

I would be willing to implement this, but it would help to have a push in the right direction.

You can use `alt+up/down` or `space/shift+space` to scroll the content.
I prefer having the arrow keys always perform the same action and not worry about where the focus is. If we wanted to scroll with up/down we'd have to un-focus the search field, scroll, then put the focus back on the search field to do another search (or to open the next result). In my opinion it's faster and easier to use `alt+up/down` and keep the focus on the search field. Thanks for the suggestion though.

Got a nasty JS runtime error, without therubyracer
-> ubuntu server 13.04
Thanks. Could you explain why this is needed? What was the error you got? (please include the stack trace)

ExecJS had no runtime, because there is no JS runtime installed on ubuntu systems by default. Maybe there is a better way to check if JS is executable by ruby, than just including a JS runtime in the Gemfile. Unfortunately I don't have the the stacktrace anymore, but it was exactly like here:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8362458/error-when-running-rails-app-execjsruntimeerror

Note:
On OSX ExecJS uses Apple JavaScriptCore and on Windows sytems it uses Microsoft Windows Script Host (JScript) so no additional JS runtime is required. But there is no JS runtime on most Linux systems.

(Trivia) Actually, any linux desktop that ships with kde or gnome 3 / cinnamon will come with a javascript runtime: `kjs`(like jsc) or `gjs`(spidermonkey). The real problem is that execjs doesn't support either of them (and they deprecated the spidermonkey runner).

The solution should just be to tell users to install nodejs when on linux, as that will also solve the problem. (untested, but looks be correct by execjs's documentation)

Thank you both for the additional info.

If the problem can be fixed by installing `nodejs` then I agree with @forivall that we should just tell users. `therubyracer` looks like a quite a big dependency.

I'll close this pull request when I update the README with the new instructions.

Using Web Workers is likely to speed up the search (no more `setTimeout`) and make the UI more responsive (workers run in a separate OS thread), but they have the downside of not being able to share objects with the main page. This would require us to duplicate the index/data in memory and may make the app slower to boot.

You can use my EasyWebWorker library for Fallback (ie) support by the way :) Just saying...
https://github.com/ramesaliyev/EasyWebWorker

When opening a search result there is currently no way to quickly browse through related entries (with the same `type`). We could improve this by adding a breadcrumb bar to the UI.

I experimented with breadcrumbs but in the end decided to stick with the sidebar as the main UI element to navigate entries. Commit 2b20c09 solves this issue by adding a link to reveal the selected search result in the sidebar.

Some documentations have very long pages that are difficult to browse through. We could improve this by adding a fixed-positioned table of contents which is automatically generated based on the current page's headings (`<h2>`, `<h3>`, etc.).

DevDocs's offline setup isn't very good, requiring people to manually install, run, and update the code. Ideally we should cache everything in the browser using a storage API.

IndexedDB is supported by most browsers but I'm not sure it can reliably store tens of thousands of files amounting to hundreds of megabytes.

Chrome also supports the FileSystem API.

@Thibaut Would https://github.com/tantaman/LargeLocalStorage be able to help solve the storage capacity limit for devdocs.io offline app? 
p.s. Thanks for devdocs.io
@gdumitrescu Looks like it could. However I think the challenging bit will be to reliably download the thousands of files that make up the documentations.
A suggestion: devdocs.io the website should remain online only, then develop desktop app with node-webkit wrapper to support offline mode.
I'd really like to see a [Dash](http://kapeli.com/dash)-like Chrome web app (offline version of the existing app) for those of us not on OS X.
Why not use a dictionary like way? Where the user manually install the data, than Devdocs uploads it onto localstorage, and updates it whenever needed.

I think @steverandy has the best solution here, to use node-webkit or similar to wrap the project into a desktop app. I don't think there is a reliable solution for holding 100's of MB's within the browser
I would love to have an easier way to access this offline. I work offline more often than not, and it is sooo hard to find good offline doumentation.
